moves.1. e4: from a najdorf imposed tournament. An interessant sacrifice.
moves.1... c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6:
here is the imposed line:
1.	e4	c5
2.	Nf3	d6
3.	d4	cxd4
4.	Nxd4	Nf6
5.	Nc3	a6
6.	Bg5
moves.6... Nbd7: i chose to defend with the second horse, without knowing very well this defence. I was not tempted by e5, because i don't like the line Bxf6, Qxf6, Nd5 that impose black to lose a tempo and offers nice suits for the white horses.
moves.7. Be2 e6: so, e6 is much more comfortable according to me, but I played various possibilities in this tournament.
moves.8. O-O Be7 9. Qd2 O-O 10. Kh1: since now, white has chosen a very quite version, without f4. I am glad about that. I hate f4... when i am black
moves.13. Nxe4 Bxh4 14. Nf3 Nxe4 15. Bxe4 Bf6: and the combination terminates with a pawn in my pocket and the pair of bishops.
moves.16. c4 Qb6: good position, as the white knight is temporarily impeached by the Bf6 and white has lost his black bishop.
moves.18... d5: let's free some space... and a trick too...
moves.19. cxd5 exd5 20. Bd3: didn't fall into it: if 20. Bxd5, then Be6, would lose it. well seen, philipdor
moves.21... Rac8 22. Rfe1: my bishop is well protected. His cannot arm mine... so what is the point? A long time plan trying to mate on 8th line?
moves.23... Rdc8 24. Rxc3 Rxc3 25. Qd2: looks like we are waiting for the draw...
moves.25... Qc7 26. Qe3: by trying to move as less as possible, and surveyboth bishop (why not remove it??) and c1 (threatening a little bit mate), black gives me the opportunity to give back the pawn and... possibly win a piece.
moves.26... d4: will you take my poor pawn?
moves.27... Bxd4: ... was your knight really protected? no, it was not, because, now, i threats mate in three if you take it.
moves.28. Qd2: and so, the knigt has been lost...
moves.29. h3: not avoinding mate yet as the queen still survey the angle.
moves.29... Bg5: so let us go, so we can exchange rooks, at least.
moves.37... b6 38. Qd3 Bd7 39. Qd5 Qc5 40. Qa8: a last one. Always some adrenaline comes in me in these case: did i forget something? a stalemate?
moves.40... Ke7 41. Qa6 Bxg3: well i can take back my pawn lost anyway
moves.42. Qe2 Be5: and you have nothing left... step by step, i just took advantage of my opponent's mistake, except maybe for the first -not-deciding- pawn.
